Not for Redistribution POLAND (Position on December 32, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Poland is the Zloty (100 groszy = 1 zloty). The exchange rate between the zloty and the currencies of countries other than members of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA),1 Albania, and the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea is determined on the basis of a weighted basket of currencies, each of which ac- counts for at least 1 percent of Poland's external current account settlements with no change in the convertible currency area. The currency composi- tion of the basket and the currency weights are defined on a monthly basis in light of current ac- count transactions in convertible currency. The value of the zloty in terms of the basket is adjusted periodically on the basis of the difference between foreign and domestic prices for traded goods and with a view to securing the profitability of major exports.2 On February 1, 1988, the external value of the zloty for the U.S. dollar was changed from Zl 320.00 = US$1 to Zl 380 = US$1; during the course of 1988, a series of smaller but frequent exchange rate adjustments were also made. The National Bank of Poland quotes exchange rates for the European Currency Unit (ECU), the SDR, and the currencies of 29 countries3 considered market economies; although it does not deal in the notes and coins of a limited number4 of the curren- cies, it stands ready to effect transactions in all of them. Buying and selling rates are set with margins of 0.5 percent around the middle rate, except for notes and coins, for which the margins are set at 2 percent. Rates are generally set at least once a week, normally on Thursdays, to become effective when they are published on the following Monday. JThe participants in the CMEA are Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslo- vakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. 2For these purposes, profitability is considered to have been achieved when the ratio of the export transaction price of a particular product to its domestic price (both expressed in a common currency) is equal to or greater than unity. 3Australian dollar, Austrian schilling, Belgian franc, Canadian dollar, Danish krone, deutsche mark, Finnish markka, French franc, Greek drachma, Indian rupee, Italian lira, Iranian rial, Irish pound, Japanese yen, Kuwaiti dinar, Lebanese pound, Libyan dinar, Luxembourg franc, Netherlands guilder, Nor- wegian krone, pound sterling, Portuguese escudo, Saudi Ara- bian riyal, Spanish peseta, Swedish krona, Swiss franc, U.S. dollar, Turkish lira, and Yugoslav dinar. 4Indian rupee, Iranian rial, Irish pound, Kuwaiti dinar, Libyan dinar, and Saudi Arabian riyal. Rates for currencies other than the U.S. dollar are based on the quoted rate for the U.S. dollar and the dollar rates for the relevant currencies in interna- tional markets on the day the rates are set. The buying and selling rates for spot transactions in U.S. dollars on December 30, 1988 were Zl 500.041 and Zl 505.061, respectively, per US$1.5 There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of the currencies of market economies for nor- mal business transactions, but a 200 percent sur- charge is applied on the sale of such currencies to Polish tourists traveling abroad. The Council of Banks sets maximum allowable commissions and charges on foreign exchange transactions in line with international practice. These levies are paid in zlotys (foreign currency) by domestic (foreign) customers. Most of Poland's trade and financial settlements with CMEA member countries are effected in trans- ferable rubles through the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC). The clearing ruble is used for most settlements with Albania and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea and for some settlements with Kampuchea and the Lao People's Democratic Republic. Official exchange rates for transferable and clearing rubles are set by the Na- tional Bank of Poland and published each Monday. Exchange rates for transferable and clearing rubles are set at the same level, and are adjusted periodically, with a view to ensuring the prof- itability of the major portion of exports to the social- ist countries. On February 1, 1988, the exchange rate for the transferable ruble (TR) was changed from Zl 140.00 = TR1 to Zl 170 = TR1, and a series of smaller but more frequent exchange rate adjust- ments were also made in 1988. Buying and selling rates for transferable and clearing rubles are quoted with a spread of 0.5 percent around the middle rate. On December 30,1988, the buying and selling rates for the zloty against transferable and clearing rubles were Zl 228.85 and Zl 231.15, respectively, per one ruble. 5Since March 15,1989, a private foreign exchange market con- sisting of licensed foreign exchange bureaus has been in opera- tion. The exchange rates in this market are determined by supply and demand conditions. 389 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 390 POLAND The National Bank of Poland also quotes weekly exchange rates for the zloty against the currencies of other CMEA member countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. These rates are based on multilateral and supplemental bilateral agreements with the socialist partners and are used for noncommercial settlements (e.g., diplomatic representation expenses, international travel, schol- arships, etc.). Buying and selling rates (including for notes and coins) are set with margins of 0.5 per- cent around the middle rate. A 30 percent surcharge is applied on the sale of these currencies for private trips abroad; the rate of surcharges applicable to trips to Czechoslovakia and Hungary is 150 percent, and to other member countries of the CMEA, 50 percent. Administration of Control The authority to make basic changes in the Ex- change Regulation Law lies with the Parliament. Implementing regulations are promulgated by the Council of Ministers and the Ministers of Finance and of Foreign Economic Relations. The authority for the enforcement of the foreign exchange regula- tions rests with the Minister of Finance, who ex- ercises related functions mainly through the Presi- dent of the National Bank of Poland. Only economic units authorized by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations (MFER) may effect exports and imports; units not so authorized must channel their imports and exports through autho- rized organizations. At the end of December 1988, 1,731 units were authorized to engage in foreign trade on a permanent basis, and 62 of these were specialized foreign trade organizations. Specialized foreign trade organizations are generally authorized to trade in all goods, subject to the limitations of their charter and rights as specified by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations. Except where a spe- cialized foreign trade organization trades in goods (such as coal) that are basic to the economy, none of these organizations has a monopoly in any one item. In addition to specialized foreign trade organiza- tions, 854 economic units had specific trading rights at the end of December 1988; 485 of these were major producing and servicing companies or were affiliated with such companies. Of these units, 815 were legal entities, such as small-scale producers and cooperatives. The remainder were individual persons, of whom 182 were foreign residents estab- lished in Poland. Subject to an appeal in the admin- istrative courts, the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations is empowered to withdraw the trading right of any unit that ceases to meet the conditions stipulated in that unit's trading authority. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Po- land has multilateral and bilateral payments agree- ments are made in the currencies and in accordance with the procedures set forth in those agreements.6 If there are no specific agreements, or if trade takes place outside the scope of the agreements, settle- ment is made in a convertible currency. Resident and Nonresident Accounts Resident Accounts Polish residents (natural persons) can hold for- eign exchange in the form of currency, stocks, bonds, etc. Four types of foreign currency accounts are available: convertible currency accounts "A," foreign exchange retention accounts "ROD," Bank PKO, S.A. deposit certificates, and socialist cur- rency accounts "S." (1) Accounts "A" can be freely credited with con- vertible currency brought or transferred from abroad and/or deposited without the requirement of a declaration of the sources of the funds .7 Ac- count holders can use the funds freely to effect transfers abroad, to buy goods and services, to fi- nance tourist travel abroad by them and their next of kin, to withdraw in the form of foreign currency or foreign exchange coupons (Bank PKO, S.A. cou- pons) for use in hard currency stores, and to effect 6At the end of December 1988, Poland had bilateral payments agreements with Albania, Bangladesh, Brazil, the People's Re- public of China, Colombia, Ecuador, India, the Islamic Republic of Iran, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Lebanon, and Nepal. Poland also had trade agreements with bilateral pay- ments features for certain commodities with Argentina, Bangla- desh, Malta, Pakistan, and Yugoslavia. Except for bilateral agree- ments with Albania, the People's Republic of China, India, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and Nepal, settle- ments under bilateral agreements were in U.S. dollars. Settle- ments with the People's Republic of China were in Swiss francs; with India, in Indian rupees; with Nepal, in pounds sterling; and in clearing rubles with Albania, Democratic Kampuchea, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, and the Lao People's Democratic Republic. 7Prior to July 1, 1988, these accounts required a declaration of the sources of funds (i.e., royalties, copyright, gifts from non- residents). Effective July 1, 1988, these accounts consolidated accounts "N," which had been available since April 1, 1985 and which could be freely credited with convertible currencies with- out a declaration requirement. Previously, funds on deposit in accounts "N" could not be transferred or used to finance travel abroad, but a f ter one year the funds were transferable to an individual's account "A." ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution POLAND 391 gifts to family members. The funds on deposit can- not be used to effect settlements between individ- uals. Withdrawals in zlotys, converted at the pre- vailing exchange rate, are freely permitted. Interest, paid in foreign exchange, is earned at the following annual rates: for accounts maintained in French francs, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, 4 percent on call deposits, 8, 9, and 10 percent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three-year term deposits; and for accounts maintained in deutsche mark and Swiss francs, 3 percent on call deposits, 7, 8, and 9 per- cent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three-year term deposits. (2) Accounts "ROD/' which came into effect on January 1, 1987, can be credited with foreign ex- change retained ("ROD" accounts) against exports in convertible currencies.8 An enterprise's retention quota is determined by the MFER in consultation with the Ministry of Finance. According to a decree of the Council of Ministers of March 1988, the authorities are planning to intro- duce, by 1990, five commodity-specific uniform re- tention rates, ranging from 10 percent to 50 percent. The new rates are to depend on the degree of pro- cessing of the exports involved instead of on the degree of import intensity of an enterprise's exports as in the past. As from June 1988, one uniform rate has applied to electronic exports. Until the com- modity structure for the uniform rates is fully estab- lished, enterprises are subject to the existing indi- vidual retention rates. The retention rate for joint ventures is 85 percent under the provisions of the 1988 Law on Economic Activity with Participation of Foreign Parties. Account holders may use the funds freely to pur- chase production-related and investment goods im- ported from the convertible currency area, either for their own use or for that of cooperating enterprises; to make certain specified debt service payments; to pay for patents; and to purchase goods produced domestically subject to the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations; and to pay for busi- ness trips and to cover marketing expenses. The funds cannot be used for settlement between indi- viduals, but they may be offered for sale at periodic 8During 1982-86, claims on ROD accounts were (with few exceptions) not the property of the enterprise. It represented priority rights to purchase foreign exchange up to a specified proportion of the foreign exchange earned from an enterprise's sale of goods and services to the convertible currency area. Provision was made in 1986-87 for a similar priority rights scheme with respect to foreign exchange earnings in transferable rubles. Retention rights are also authorized for exports to bilat- eral payments agreement countries that are not members of the CMEA. In addition to the ROD accounts available to exporters of most commodities, there are a number of other retention schemes that apply to particular exports or exporters. auctions held by the Export Development Bank. Interest is paid in foreign exchange at the annual rates of 3, 4, and 5 percent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three-year deposits. Deposits on current accounts do not earn interest. (3) Bank PKO deposit certificates are accepted by the Bank PKO, S.A. in convertible currencies. The sources of funds need not be declared. Interest pay- able in foreign currency after each six-month period is earned at the following annual rates: 3, 8, and 9 percent, respectively, on one-, two-, and three- year deposits. The deposit certificates are issued in U.S. dollars in denominations of US$100 and US$500.9 (4) Accounts "S" can be credited with socialist country currencies derived from wages, property sales, inheritances, etc., and with transfers from other accounts "S." Funds in these accounts are freely transferable abroad (to other socialist coun- tries) and may be freely withdrawn in any socialist country currency, with conversion effected at the national currency rates quoted by the National Bank of Poland. Deposits of call money earn interest at 3 percent a year, and one-year term deposits earn interest at 4.5 percent a year. Resident individuals and enterprises may hold foreign exchange accounts abroad with the express permission of the National Bank of Poland. Such permission is granted only on "proof of necessity." Nonresident Accounts Nonresident juridical and physical peersons are free to keep both convertible currency and zloty accounts. Use of zloty accounts requires the permis- sion of the National Bank of Poland. (1) Nonresidents may maintain convertible cur- rency accounts (accounts "C") at the National Bank of Poland, the Bank Handlowy, and the Bank PKO, S.A. These accounts can be credited with funds brought or transferred into Poland, with transfers from other accounts "C," and with convertible cur- rency amounts legally acquired in Poland. Deposits are freely transferable abroad, and may be used for purchases from hard currency stores and to make gifts to residents. The funds earn interest in foreign currency. Interest rates on accounts "C" of physical persons are fixed by banks and are paid at an annual 9These deposit certificates are distinct from Bank PKO cou- pons, which can be used to buy "internal exports" in hard cur- rency stores and other designated sales outlets. Since Novem- ber 1, 1987, the Bank PKO, S.A. has offered to convert these coupons into zlotys at a small discount from the exchange rate prevailing in the parallel market. Effective June 16, 1988, the Bank PKO, S.A. stood ready to sell (buy) these coupons to (from) Polish residents in return for zlotys, also at rates close to the parallel market exchange rate. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 392 POLAND rate in the range of 3 percent to 5 percent for de- mand deposits, and in the range of 7 percent to 11 percent for term deposits (depending on the account currency, the time limit, and the rates on international money markets). Interest rates on ac- counts "C" of juridical persons are fixed at the same rates, except demand deposits, which do not earn interest. (2) Nonresidents are free to open and hold zloty accounts. Depositors may be asked to declare the source of the zlotys when making deposits into such accounts. This declaration requirement aims to ensure that payments into the accounts result from contracts or other operations that comply with the provisions of the foreign exchange law. Drawings on a zloty account require a foreign exchange permit, which is normally granted without restrictions for any internal disbursements. Apart from zlotys le- gally earned in Poland, these accounts may also be credited with foreign exchange converted to zlotys at the current exchange rate. Permits for conversion back to foreign exchange or for foreign exchange transfers abroad are normally granted. These ac- counts do not pay interest; however, nonresidents may also deposit their earnings on savings bank books, on which interest is paid. Deposits on zloty accounts may be transferred to other nonresidents or residents. Such transfers require a foreign ex- change permit, except gifts for residents. Permits for transfers to nonresidents are granted only for transfers to family members. Permits for transfers to residents are granted without any restriction. Imports and Exports All imports and exports are subject to a licensing requirement. Licenses are issued by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations or by its "full-powers" agent employed by the economic unit applying for the license. The customs authority issues licenses not exceeding Zl 100,000 in value for gifts and sou- venirs. Only economic units with permanent trad- ing rights are eligible to have a licensing agent of the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations in residence. Since July 1,1988, there are two types of licenses: general and individual licenses. (Previously, there were only individual licenses.) General licenses ap- ply to an estimated 80 percent of exports and im- ports (in value terms). Eligible items include all imports and exports that are centrally balanced, transactions under long-term cooperation agree- ments, imports for re-exports, imports needed for production financed by ROD (enterprises) ac- counts, raw material imports for export production, imports for internal export, and all non-centrally- balanced exports in convertible currencies that are settled in cash. Individual licenses apply to an esti- mated 20 percent of exports and imports and cover special transactions, such as those settled on credit terms, barter transactions, transactions under bilat- eral agreement, leasing, or where general licenses are denied. These licenses are issued by the Minis- try of Foreign Economic Relations or by those for- eign trade enterprises to whom this Ministry dele- gates authority. General licenses are normally issued for a period of one year but may be issued for a period up to three years in appropriate cases. These licenses are issued to most foreign trade enterprises and units engaged in foreign trade, except very small units that are engaged in a wide range of products. The license stipulates the list of permissible products and applicable limits (in terms of quantity and value) in the case of centrally balanced exports and imports; no additional licenses are required if the limits are exceeded by less than 5 perrcent. For non- centrally-balanced transactions, the requirement depends on the items in question. For certain con- sumption items no limits are required. For inter- mediate products, estimates of domestic demand that should be met are provided as a guideline. The Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations must render its decision on the issuance of a license within ten days after an application is filed. No fur ther license from the foreign exchange authority is required for export or import and the perfor- mance or use of related services. Trade in certain goods is prohibited for social reasons under the penal code. Individual licenses are readily granted at no cost, provided that the relevant regulations are observed and that the transactions are in line with national plan allocations. Contracts do not become valid, nor may payment orders be drawn, until a license has been issued, except for intergovernmental agree- ments and instantaneous contracts, such as those made on a metals exchange. A license application must be filed with the appropriate authority within seven days af ter agreement on a contract is reached. A license remains valid until the final delivery date for the goods, or until the date of final payment; in specific cases, the validity period of a license may be extended. For data collection purposes, the eco- nomic unit must forward a general authorization and a license to the Foreign Trade Information Cen- ter within two days of their respective issuance; the documents are returned to the units within ten days of their registration by the Center. On the basis of the registered documents and the utilization rec- ords that the units are required to keep, the customs ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution POLAND 393 administration monitors whether goods are traded according to valid documents. It also has the au- thority to inspect all relevant documents and to issue instructions for eliminating irregularities. In the event of changes in the contracted provi- sions, the economic unit must notify the relevant authorities (the Ministry of Foreign Economic Rela- tions or its agent, and the Information Center) of the necessary changes in the license within seven days of receipt of the documentation, stating the reason for the changes. In the event of a change of more than 5 percent in the foreign currency price, or mistakes or errors in data, a new license must be issued, which automatically and simultaneously re- scinds the former version. If a license is not fully utilized, the economic unit must declare this to the appropriate authorities within 14 days a f ter con- firmation of this fact. Such a declaration is not re- quired if the underutilization amounts to less than Zl 50,000, or does not exceed 5 percent of the price or volume stated in the license. Settlement in for- eign exchange is authorized and effected upon re- ceipt, and according to the terms, of valid docu- ments for settlement. There are no import quotas. Foreign exchange allocation plans, which are prepared by the Plan- ning Commission in consultation with the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, Ministry of Finance, and the National Bank of Poland, are approved by the Council of Ministers on an annual basis. The annual plan determines import needs by com- modity groupings and value for centrally financed imports. These are balanced against financing ac- cording to priorities, with raw and intermediate products being the most important. For de- centralized imports, the annual plan specifies the global ceiling. In 1988, about 62 percent of convert- ible currency imports were financed centrally; these imports, largely intermediate products purchased in line with the needs of the annual plan, are dis- tributed to the enterprises by the State. Total enter- prise accounts financed about 28 percent of imports (of which ROD accounts accounted for 19 percent), and special targeted auctions financed about 4 per- cent of imports, usually of specified commodities. A portion of the remaining foreign exchange available jfor imports was allocated (under the control of branch ministries) for enterprise needs related to government contracts and operational programs. Separately, the branch ministries are in control of exchange for their own requirements. Under the 1988 foreign exchange allocation plan, two targeted auctions of foreign exchange were in- troduced to expand the scope for the decentralized financing of imports: (1) auctions of a specified pool of foreign exchange to nonexporting producers for importation of 23 specified commodities; and (2) auctions of a specified amount of earnings from internal exports of state-run hard currency outlets for domestic trading organizations having no direct access to foreign exchange. In general, residents may import reasonable quantities of goods for noncommercial use free of customs duty. Quantity limits may be set on a product-by-product basis. There are some special regulations pertaining to border trade with the U.S.S.R. Certain imports and exports are subject to taxes and levies and subsidies in connection with the Equalization Settlement System (see below). The subsidy rates for agricultural exports to the non- ruble and ruble areas are 20 percent and 50 percent, respectively. Other than in this connection, there are no direct taxes on exports. Imports are subject to stamp duties and turnover taxes at rates similar to those on domestic goods. Exports are free from turnover taxes. Duties and turnover taxes on im- ports for export production are refunded. Economic units are entitled to relief from income tax and the tax on excessive wage increases based on the value of their exports. Rates of relief are set annually by the Minister of Finance. Most trade with CMEA member countries, Al- bania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is conducted under bilateral trade and pay- ments agreements negotiated annually within the framework of five-year bilateral trade and payments agreements. Imports from these countries may be exempted from customs duties. An Equalization Settlement System (ESS) applies to exports and imports of commodities for which domestic prices are set by the Government —i.e., which are subject to "administrative" pricing, and where the established administrative price differs from the external transaction price; the latter price is equal to the price expressed in foreign exchange converted to zlotys at the exchange rate quoted by the National Bank of Poland. To compensate for these price differentials, the ESS, which is operated under the authority of the Ministry of Foreign Eco- nomic Relations, credits or debits the relevant eco- nomic unit with an equalization amount. All goods for which there are official (government-set) prices are subject to the system, although the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations has the right to delete products from the list. On a case-by-case basis, the system is also applied to goods subject to contract prices, with the decision whether to do so being negotiated between the Ministry of Foreign Eco- nomic Relations and the economic unit concerned. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 394 POLAND Unless specifically exempted, all foreign currency receipts from exports must be declared, repatriated, and surrendered to the Polish foreign exchange banks. Exchange received under contractual pay- ment terms must be surrendered immediately; other exchange must be surrendered within one month of its receipt. Nonresidents may take out of Poland, free of customs duty, souvenirs not exceeding Zl 2,000 in value. However, they may export goods bought in hard currency stores up to the value of foreign cur- rencies declared at the point of first entry and ad- justed for reasonable living expenses. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for invisible expenses arising from mer- chandise transactions, including insurance and transportation costs, are permitted freely if related to trade transactions fulfilling licensing require- ments. All other invisible transactions are carried out under either a general or an individual permit. Foreign exchange for such payments is made avail- able automatically once the transaction has been authorized. In principle, permission for tourist travel to coun- tries other than members of the CMEA, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is granted only if means of support abroad is assured. This requirement can be met in one of the following ways: (1) living expenses while abroad are covered by nonresidents; (2) living expenses while abroad are covered from the resident's own funds in a resi- dent account in foreign convertible currencies or, in special cases, from an allowance obtained from the National Bank of Poland; and (3) travel is with an authorized tourist group. Travelers use the funds in their account "A." Effective December 1,1988, trav- elers may take out of Poland US$500 without official permission. In special cases, foreign currency travel al- lowances may be granted by the National Bank of Poland for travel to convertible currency countries. These allowances are subject to a 200 percent for- eign exchange tax. For official and business travel, separate allowances are established by the Ministry of Finance to reflect reasonable costs. Nonresident travelers to Poland are expected to fulfill minimum living expenses by converting a required amount of foreign exchange (equivalent to US$15 per day) into zlotys. When leaving Poland, tourists from convertible currency area countries can reconvert zlotys up to the equivalent brought into Poland, provided the amount is not more than the amount originally converted into zlotys less the required conversion amounts. Without a permit from the foreign exchange authority, residents may bring into or take out of the country domestic cur- rency in an amount not exceeding Zl 10,000 a per- son, of which the largest permissible banknote is Zl 5,000 and the largest permissible coin is Zl 50. Non- residents from CMEA countries may bring into or take out of the country zlotys up to the amount certified by their domestic banks. Special exchange regulations apply to invisible transactions with CMEA countries: residents visit- ing CMEA countries are entitled to an allowance of Zl 80,000 a person every two years, and one half of this amount for each child up to the age of 7 years. In addition, funds in accounts "S" may be used. A portion of the travel allowance may be given in the currency of the country to be visited in amounts determined by that country's regulations. For the rest, travelers must acquire traveler's checks in the currency of destination. All conversions are effected with a 30 percent surcharge. Under certain circumstances, foreign exchange may be made available for study abroad. Students' living expenses and tuition fees abroad must be covered by scholarships or financial support from nonresident relatives. Transfers abroad by nonresi- dent workers in Poland, other than in the context of employment in joint ventures, are determined on the basis of agreements between domestic and for- eign institutions or enterprises. Nonresident em- ployees of joint ventures may transfer abroad up to 50 percent of their income. Profits on direct investment by nonresidents, other than those from joint ventures, can be trans- ferred abroad up to a maximum annual amount of 10 percent of invested capital. If the investment yields a convertible currency export-to-import sur- plus in any fiscal year, up to 50 percent of the sur- plus can be transferred abroad, provided the trans- fer does not exceed 50 percent of net profit after taxes. The Minister of Finance may permit a transfer in excess of 50 percent of the surplus. On liquida- tion, the investor can transfer abroad the proceeds from the sale of the remaining assets sold in foreign currency. For joint ventures incorporated under the 1988 Law on Economic Activity with Participation of Foreign Parties, there are no limits on the transfer abroad by nonresidents of profits accruing from export proceeds net of import costs. Capital Parliament annually sets an upper limit on Po- land's permissible external indebtedness. Within this limit, foreign borrowing takes place on the basis of intergovernmental agreements and in various forms of bank and commercial credits. Under the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution POLAND 395 provisions of the banking law, the National Bank of Poland, Bank Handlowy, Bank PKO, S.A., and the Export Development Bank are empowered to bor- row abroad, on short to long term, and to extend foreign credits. The Minister of Finance sets limits on the foreign borrowing of the banks. With approval from the Minister of Finance, so- cialized enterprises may take financial loans from foreign banks. Subject to approval by the Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, in consultation with the Minister of Finance, socialized enterprises are allowed commercial credits granted by foreign banks or suppliers to finance imports. To borrow abroad, a socialized enterprise also requires the consent of the domestic bank that holds its basic account. The Government has established general direc- tives for extending commercial credits relating to foreign trade activities. Socialized enterprises may extend such credits only with approval from the Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, who pre- scribes the contractual conditions in each case. Ne- gotiable export documents are discountable by for- eign banks. Direct foreign investment in Poland is allowed in the field of small-scale industry under the law of July 6, 1982. A permit is required from the chief administrative office ("voivodship") of the area where the investment is to be located. The permit, which is valid for up to 20 years, is issued after the investor has lodged a "founding deposit" in con- vertible currency with the Bank PKO, S.A. in an amount equivalent to US$50,000. A foreign investor is obliged to import inputs in kind in the form of machinery and equipment, materials, technology, etc. The value of such goods cannot be lower than the minimum founding deposit, which yields inter- est according to the normal bank rate for accounts "C" and can be withdrawn after certification by the voivodship office that the investment project is complete. Upon liquidation of investment, a foreign investor can transfer abroad the proceeds from the sale of assets sold in foreign currency. A nonresident investor in a small-scale industry can obtain zloty credits from the Bank PKO, S.A. for the financing of both current production destined for the domestic market and for exports and invest- ment outlays associated with such production; such credits cannot exceed 30 percent of working capital for current production. Investment credits are lim- ited to a maximum of 30 percent of the estimated cost of the project for investments. A nonresident investor is exempt from income tax payments for three years, provided that one third of the tax lia- bility is invested in Poland. The maximum tax rate for nonresident investors is 80 percent, but tax al- lowances are granted if production is directed to final domestic consumption or for export, as well as when new investment projects are undertaken. In the latter case, allowances of up to 50 percent of the cost of the project may be granted. In practice, the effective tax rate has averaged 60-65 percent of in- come. For export production, the investor receives the general exemption from custom duties on im- ports related to such production. Under the 1986 Law on Companies with Foreign Capital Participation, direct investment by nonresi- dents is also allowed in all but a few sectors (e.g., defense) in the form of joint ventures with local firms.10 The maximum tax rate on a joint venture is 50 percent, and rates as low as 10 percent may be applied, depending on the share of exports in total production. Joint ventures also enjoy an initial tax holiday of two years. Foreign investment by residents, either to estab- lish subsidiaries or affiliates, or to acquire an inter- est in a foreign enterprise, must be approved by the relevant Minister, as well as by the Minister of Fi- nance in his capacity as the foreign exchange authority. All categories of capital transfers, including gifts, by resident natural persons require a foreign ex- change permit. However, for certain categories, such as inheritances, transfers are authorized on the basis of agreements and reciprocity with other countries. An annual limit of Zl 1 million is applied to all capital transfers. Emigrants to other countries must obtain an individual permit from the National Bank of Poland to take out their convertible currency deposits with domestic banks. Other financial as- sets may be deposited in a nonresident zloty account. Except in the form of an inheritance, nonresi- dents may acquire real estate or other immovable property in Poland only with the permission of the foreign exchange authority. Gold Resident individuals may hold gold in any form. Trading in gold, other than jewelry, is subject to permission from the foreign exchange authorities. 10This law was superseded on December 23, 1988 by the Law on Economic Activity with Participation of Foreign Parties, which became effective January 1, 1989. Under the 1988 law, the max- imum tax rate is 40 percent, the initial tax holiday period is extended to three years, and the tax holiday for joint ventures in preferential sectors can be extended at the discretion of the Council of Ministers by up to an additional three years. The retention rate under ROD accounts for joint ventures is set at 85 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Portugal is the Portuguese Es- cudo, the exchange rate of which is adjusted monthly1 in relation to a basket of currencies, weighted according to their importance in Portu- gal's international merchandise trade. Depreciation objectives for the effective exchange rate of the es- cudo are announced periodically by the authorities. During 1988, the monthly rate of devaluation was 0.4 percent in the first quarter, 0.3 percent in the second, and 0.25 percent in the third; it was further lowered in the fourth quarter in order to reach an annual rate of depreciation of 3.5 percent. Throughout 1987 the monthly rate of depreciation was 0.5 percent to 0.2 percent a month, and the effective exchange rate declined by 3.5 percent on average over the year against the basket of curren- cies. On December 30, 1988, the authorized banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were Esc 146.11 and Esc 146.63, respectively, per US$1. Official exchange rates for the U.S. dollar and other currencies2 are determined during the fixing ses- sion, in which the Bank of Portugal and the autho- rized banks participate. There is a fee of 0.9 percent on all sales of foreign exchange. The Macao pataca is pegged to the Hong Kong dollar at a parity rate of P 1.03 = HK$1. Commercial banks may deal in foreign exchange with the Bank of Portugal, among themselves, with other domestic nonbank economic agents, and with banks abroad. Foreign exchange transactions of commercial banks with the Bank of Portugal are, in principle, limited to the spot market. Spot or for- ward foreign exchange operations are carried out at freely negotiated exchange rates between commer- cial banks and their customers. The forward foreign exchange market began to operate in February 1987. Commercial banks are allowed to conduct forward transactions for periods of up to one year. Foreign exchange operations between banks and nonbank economic agents are always linked to purchases or sales of foreign exchange with escudos as a result of imports or exports of goods, services, current invis- 1 Since 1977, except from December 1985 to April 1986. 2Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Cana- dian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, the ECU, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Greek drachmas, Italian lire, Irish pounds, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, South African rand, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and Macao patacas. ibles, or capital movements. There are no restric- tions on foreign exchange deals among banks in Portugal and banks abroad except forward pur- chases of escudos from nonresidents, which are not authorized. There are no restrictions on foreign ex- change deals in the interbank foreign exchange market. The degree of foreign exchange risks that banks are authorized to take must fall within the limits established by the Bank of Portugal for the foreign exchange positions of banks in terms of for- eign currencies. On January 1, 1988, the Bank of Portugal became a participant in the European Monetary Coopera- tion Fund (EMCF), enabling it to participate in the mechanism for the creation of official ECUs through swaps of 20 percent of its gold and dollar reserves. These swaps are renewable every three months so as to ensure that contributions to EMCF represent at least 20 percent of the reserves of the Bank of Portugal. Portugal formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as from September 12, 1988. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Bank of Portugal on behalf of the Ministry of Finance, with the assistance of the commercial banks autho- rized for this purpose. Foreign trade policy is formulated and imple- mented by the Ministry of Commerce and Tourism; for statistical purposes, imports are subject to prior registration with the Ministry. The Director-General of Foreign Commerce in this Ministry is responsible for administering trade controls. Import declara- tions are issued by a department within the Direc- torate General of Foreign Commerce or by other authorized executive departments. Prescription of Currency Transactions with Turkey are settled on a monthly basis through a clearing account maintained in U.S. dollars. Export transactions with other countries may be settled from a nonresident account with a resident bank in the quoted currencies (see foot- note 2) or in U.S. dollars. Payments to nonresidents may be made by crediting escudos to a nonresident account. The Portuguese escudo may be accepted as currency of settlement for exports of goods, ser- vices, and capital transfers to Portugal. 397 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 398 PORTUGAL Nonresident Accounts In 1988, the Bank of Portugal issued new regula- tions concerning nonresident accounts in escudos and in foreign currencies. It also introduced changes in regulations concerning emigrants' deposits. 1. Nonresident Accounts in Escudos The opening of nonresident accounts in escudos is free. They must be non-interest-bearing demand accounts, and exceptions must be especially autho- rized by the Bank of Portugal. Nonresident accounts in escudos may be cred- ited, without prior authorization of the Bank of Por- tugal, with: (1) the amount of escudos correspond- ing to transfers from abroad or sales of foreign currency and other means of payments denomi- nated in foreign currencies; (2) the amount of es- cudos corresponding to payments to nonresidents of Portuguese imports of goods and services as well as outflows of private capital duly authorized by current legislation; and (3) transfers from other non- resident accounts in escudos. Nonresident accounts in escudos may be debited, without prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal, for (1) transfers abroad resulting from the purchase of foreign currency with escudos; (2) payments to residents for Portuguese exports of goods, services, current invisibles, and private capital outflows, duly authorized by current legislation; and (3) transfers to other nonresident accounts in es- cudos. For all other debit and credit operations, the authorization of the Bank of Portugal is required. The granting of credit in the form of overdrafts on the accounts described above requires the authori- zation of the Bank of Portugal. 2. Nonresident Accounts in Foreign Currency Opening and transactions of nonresident ac- counts in foreign currency —demand accounts and time accounts up to one year —are subject to restric- tion. Time accounts of more than one year require special authorization of the Bank of Portugal. Inter- est rates are freely negotiable. Accounts may be denominated in any foreign currency acceptable to the banks. 3. Emigrants' Accounts Portuguese emigrants may open three types of deposit accounts: emigrants' savings accounts (time account in escudos); joint accounts with residents (deposit or time accounts in escudos); and time deposit accounts in foreign currency. a. Emigrants' savings account may be credited with remittances from abroad received through the banking system or in the form of an international postal order, with the equivalent in escudos of exter- nal means of payment sold to credit institutions by emigrants, with transfers from other accounts of the same owner (emigrants' savings accounts or ac- counts in foreign currency), and with interest due on such deposits. These accounts may be debited without restriction. b. Joint accounts with residents are similar to resi- dents' deposit accounts and can be in the form of either demand or time deposits. These accounts may be credited with funds from abroad (similar to crediting emigrants' savings deposits) or with funds from domestic sources. These accounts may be debited without restriction, except transfers to emigrants' savings accounts or abroad. Transfers abroad are subject to the regulations that apply to current transfers. c. Time deposit accounts in foreign currencies may be credited with remittances from abroad, with sales of external means of payment by emigrants, and with transfers from other accounts in foreign cur- rency of the same owner and with interest due. These accounts may be debited without restriction. Interest income from all types of emigrants' de- posits is subject to a tax at the rate of 3.3 percent a year. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Opening of resident accounts in foreign currency requires special authorization of the Bank of Portu- gal, unless the holder is a bank. Without prior au- thorization, commercial banks may open, at home or abroad, demand accounts or time accounts up to one year in any currency at freely negotiated inter- est rates. Imports and Import Payments Prior registration is required for all imports valued at over Esc 150,000. Import declarations serve statis- tical purposes, and they are granted automatically in four to five days. Imports of certain products are prohibited or are allowed only under specific condi- tions, mainly for reasons of health, public order, and the prevention of commercial fraud. Any physical or juridical entity may be an importer. Most imports from all sources are effected on the basis of import declarations. For imports free of quantitative restriction, the importer is required to present the import contract and Form 8 of EC Single Customs Declaration to obtain the foreign exchange necessary to settle the contract. For agricultural products covered by a common market organiza- tion, an import certificate may be required as deter- mined by this organization. For imports subject to quantitative restrictions, an import license is re- quired. The validity of the import declaration is ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL 399 6 months for customs clearance purposes, and the settlement period is 12 months. Payments beyond 12 months after customs clearance require the ap- proval of the Bank of Portugal. According to the Act of Accession of Portugal to the European Communities (EC), imports of some agricultural products are subject to temporary re- strictions when originating in EC and third coun- tries. As regards other industrial products, there is a list of 15 products (including automobiles) that are subject to quantitative restrictions only when orig- inating in third countries. A more extensive re- stricted list applies to Japan, which includes man- ufactured raw materials, some textile fibers, and a small number of finished products, including motorcycles. Payments for Invisibles Payments to foreign countries for current invis- ibles must be made through credit institutions au- thorized to operate in foreign exchange and are generally free of quantitative restrictions, although prior verification by the Bank of Portugal or other credit institutions properly authorized is required. For most transactions, ceilings are specified for the amounts of foreign exchange that authorized credit institutions may grant freely. For payments to countries with which Portugal does not maintain special clearing arrangements, the authorized credit institutions may grant foreign exchange up to the equivalent of Esc 7.5 million a transaction for most types of invisibles. For tourism and other private travel (except for business trips and for study or medical treatment purposes, which are not subject to limits when duly evidenced), they may grant the equivalent of Esc 150,000 a person a trip. In addition, tourists may take out of the coun- try Esc 50,000 in local currency for each trip.3 The export of larger amounts of domestic or foreign currency requires the prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal. Applications must be submitted to the Bank of Portugal for exchange for payments of items not referred to above and for payments in excess of the above-mentioned limits. Under the provisions of the Foreign Investment Code, individual remittances of profits and divi- dends and the repatriation of proceeds of liquida- tion of direct foreign investment in Portugal are free 3The use of credit cards abroad has been liberalized since Jan- uary 2, 1986. However, legislation in force envisages the pos- sibility of reimposing restrictions by the Bank of Portugal when- ever deemed necessary. Also, payments of travel and accommodation expenses abroad for tourism purposes have been liberalized, if paid through a Portuguese travel agency. of restrictions, although prior declaration to the Bank of Portugal is required. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports, which are not subject to quantitative restrictions under EC regulations, are free of restric- tions. The export of some textiles is subject to ad- ministrative cooperation with EC countries for a period of two years. The export of a few com- modities may be restricted, mainly to ensure ade- quate supplies to domestic industries and to avoid depletion of local resources. These exports require an export license, as is the case for iron scraps. Exports without concomitant foreign exchange in- flow require prior authorization by the Bank of Portugal. Exporters are required to sell to an authorized bank the total amount of the export proceeds within specified periods. The period for settlement of mer- chandise exports is, as a rule, fixed at six months from the date of customs clearance. Payment of commission expenses abroad and freight, insur- ance, or other charges is subject to the regulations that govern payments for invisibles. Proceeds from Invisibles Portuguese residents may freely receive pay- ments in escudos and in foreign currency for invis- ibles from residents of countries with which Portu- gal does not have special clearing arrangements. Such receipts may be effected through credit in- stitutions and do not require prior authorization by the Bank of Portugal. Receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Authorized banks are not permit- ted to receive or to pay domestic or foreign bank notes or coin for settlement of external transactions. There are no limits on the amount of domestic currency notes resident and nonresident travelers may bring into the country. Capital As from January 1, 1986, the effective date of accession to the EC, foreign exchange regulations distinguish between capital transactions with resi- dents of EC member countries and residents of non- EC member countries, although in most cases the distinction is not relevant in practice. Most pay- ments will be free of restrictions after a transitional period of four to seven years, depending on the type of transaction. Foreign direct investments in Portu- gal are permitted in all sectors except those which, under the general law, are closed to private enter- prise corporations. Since July 1986, the new foreign ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 400 PORTUGAL investment regulations stipulate that new direct in- vestment projects are subject only to prior declara- tion to the Foreign Investment Institute, and will be considered approved in the absence of a reply from the Institute within 60 days. However, foreign direct investment in the form of long-term loans is subject to a prior authorization by the Bank of Portugal. In both cases, in 1988 new foreign direct investment by EC residents of less than ECU 2.1 million was auto- matically approved, and this amount will be in- creased by ECU 0.3 million a year until 1990 when foreign direct investments will be free of restric- tions. The transfer of the proceeds of liquidation of foreign direct investment including capital gains is free of restrictions. Foreign direct investments in EC countries by Portuguese residents require special authorization until 1993, when they will be free of restrictions. However, since November 1988, investments in EC and other member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) are liberalized up to Esc 20 million and Esc 10 mil- lion, respectively. Purchases of real estate in Portugal are free of restrictions since January 1, 1986, except housing already built and land for agricultural purposes, which are subject to a special authorization by the Bank of Portugal until 1991. The transfer of the proceeds of their liquidation was free of restrictions up to ECU 140,000 in 1988, and it will be increased by ECU 20,000 a year until 1991. Purchases of real estate in EC countries by Por- tuguese residents will be free of restrictions as of 1993. Purchases by nonresidents of domestic se- curities quoted in the stock exchange have been free of restrictions since January 1, 1986. Purchases by Portuguese residents of securities quoted in the stock exchange and issued by EC residents will remain subject to a special authorization of the Bank of Portugal until 1991. However, investment funds are, in principle, allowed to be invested in foreign securities listed in stock exchanges of OECD mem- ber countries up to 10 percent of their portfolio. Subscription of securities issued by the European Investment Bank, the European Economic Com- munity (EEC), the European Atomic Energy Com- munity (EURATOM), and the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was free of restrictions up to ECU 21 million in 1988, and it will be increased by ECU 3 million a year until 1991, when such pur- chases become free of restrictions. Most trade credits and personal capital move- ments have also been free of restrictions since Jan- uary 1, 1986. The remaining transactions continue to be subject to prior authorization by the Bank of Portugal and, in the case of loans exceeding Esc 800 million and with a maturity of more than one year, approval of the Minister of Finance is also required. The revisions of Portugal's reservations concern- ing the OECD Code of Liberalization of Capital Movements have generally extended liberalization of capital transactions with the OECD countries, which is similar to that extended to the EC member countries. Gold Residents may hold gold in any form in Portugal. The purchase, sale, import, export, or re-export of bullion or coined and unworked gold, when carried out between Portugal and foreign countries, is sub- ject to special advance authorization from the Bank of Portugal. There is a free market for gold in Macao, in which both residents of Macao and nonresidents who are not resident in Portugal may freely trade among themselves in bars, leaves, and coins. Imports and exports of gold, unless made by or on behalf of the Macao monetary authorities, require licenses issued by the Commissioner for Economy. Not for Redistribution QATAR (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Qatar is the Qatar Riyal, which is pegged to the SDR at QR 4.7619 = SDR 1. Qatar has established margins of 7.25 percent around this rate. The Qatar Monetary Agency sets daily market rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, and the pound sterling. On December 31,1988, the buying and selling rates for the Qatar riyal in terms of the U.S. dollar were QR 3.6385 and QR 3.6415, respectively, per US$1. The commercial banks' exchange rates for trans- actions in U.S. dollars are based on the Monetary Agency's buying and selling rates. A spread of QR 0.87 is applied to exchange transactions with the public. The commercial banks' buying and selling rates for other currencies are based on the Monetary Agency's rates for the U.S. dollar and market rates for the currency concerned against the U.S. dollar. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official banking sector. In the commercial banking sector, importers may purchase foreign ex- change in the forward market. Qatar formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agree- ment, with effect from June 4, 1973. Administration of Control The Qatar Monetary Agency is the exchange con- trol authority, but there is at present no exchange control legislation. Import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Economy and Commerce. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel and South Africa are prohibited. No other prescription of currency re- quirements are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel and South Africa are pro- hibited. Also prohibited are imports of pork and its derivatives. Imports of alcoholic beverages, fire- arms, ammunition, and certain drugs are subject to licensing for reasons of health or public policy. Oth- erwise, imports are not restricted. There are no restrictions on payments for permitted imports. Im- ports of general goods are subject to a customs duty at the rate of 4.0 percent, which is the minimum rate applied by member countries of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf (GCC). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel and South Africa are pro- hibited. Otherwise, all commodities may be ex- ported freely. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the cur- rency involved. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments may not be made to or received from Israel and South Africa. Otherwise, there are no limitations on payments for and proceeds from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or non- residents, although payments may not be made to or received from Israel and South Africa. Foreign participation in small- and medium-scale agri- cultural and industrial enterprises with invested capital of less than QR 250,000 is prohibited. For- eign participation in large-scale enterprises requires Qatar nationals to control at least 51 percent of capi- tal unless the enterprise is viewed as facilitating the provision of a public service, in which case the Qatari participation requirement may be waived. In addition to this requirement, the enterprise must have a domestic value added of at least 40 percent. Foreigners other than nationals of member states of the GCC are prohibited from business ownership in the trade sector. For major industrial projects, it is government policy to assume a minimum of 70 per- cent ownership. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents and nonresidents (including private persons) may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell 401 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 402 QATAR gold in any form, at home or abroad. For trading purposes, the selling and buying of gold and pre- cious metals are subject to import license and customs duty. Transactions involving Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Changes During 1988 No significant changes occurred in the exchange and trade system. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ROMANIA (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Romania is the Romanian Leu. The exchange rate used for all trade transactions in convertible currencies is the commercial rate, which is defined in terms of a basket of six currencies reflecting the geographical pattern of Romania's trade and payments. Weekly adjustments are made in the leu/U.S. dollar rate (and, correspondingly, in the rates for all other quoted currencies) in such a way as to maintain the central point on the basket peg. On December 30, 1988, the commercial ex- change rate was lei 14.37 = US$1. The National Bank of Romania quotes rates for 16 other curren- cies defined as "fully convertible"1 and for the Fin- nish markka, the Greek drachma, the Indian rupee, the Israeli new sheqel, the Portuguese escudo, the Spanish peseta, the Turkish lira, and the Yugoslav dinar, based on the rates for these currencies against the U.S. dollar in the countries concerned. For members of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA),2 Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, the currency used for commercial transactions is the transferable ruble (TR); on December 30, 1988, the transferable ruble rate was lei 15.50 = TR 1. For exchange rate purposes, payments for insur- ance and transportation connected with trade are considered as trade transactions. The commercial exchange rate applies to all trade and most services transactions, and the noncommercial exchange rate applies to non-trade-related services and transfers, with the exception of travel through tourist organi- zations. Capital transactions are settled at the com- mercial rate. The noncommercial rate is pegged to the same basket of currencies as the commercial rate and is also adjusted on a weekly basis; the rate was lei 8.84 = US$1 on December 30, 1988. For the nontransport component of the expenses for individual travel to nonsocialist countries and Yugoslavia and for certain other expenditures abroad, such as personal subscriptions to periodi- cals and legal penalties, a 100 percent tax is levied Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Cana- dian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Irish pounds, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Luxembourg francs, Nether- lands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, and Swiss francs. 2The participants in the CMEA are Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslo- vakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. on purchases of foreign exchange. For nontrade transactions with the CMEA countries, Albania, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, spe- cial exchange rates are established by multilateral or bilateral agreement; for transactions with the U.S.S.R., this rate is lei 8.30 per rub 1. For persons working abroad in technical assis- tance jobs or as professionals, such as medical doc- tors, daily allowances are paid in foreign exchange, and any accumulated surpluses can be converted into lei at the noncommercial exchange rate. Roma- nians working in international organizations or joint ventures, as well as those occasionally receiving foreign exchange income, are required to repatriate a part of it as a contribution to the fund for training of staff involved in international cooperation and for the maintenance of their families at home. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. Administration of Control Foreign trade is a state monopoly. Import and export transactions are effected by foreign trade en- terprises and other authorized units. Import and export transactions are subject to authorizations granted by the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Inter- national Economic Cooperation. In the issuing of authorizations, the provisions of existing trade agreements are taken into account. Foreign cur- rency proceeds from exports are sold to the Roma- nian Bank for Foreign Trade; foreign currency re- quired for import payments is purchased from that bank. Exchange control is administered by the Min- istry of Finance, the National Bank, and the Roma- nian Bank for Foreign Trade. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Ro- mania has bilateral payments agreements are made in currencies and in accordance with the procedures set forth in those agreements.3 If no agreement 3The countries with which bilateral payments agreements were in force as of December 31,1988 were Albania, Bangladesh, the People's Republic of China, Colombia, Ghana, India, the Islamic Republic of Iran, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. Settlements with Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam take place through the multilateral pay- ments system within the International Bank for Economic Cooperation. 403 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 404 ROMANIA exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Certain commercial settlements with Tur- key are made in U.S. dollars under a credit agree- ment. Permitted foreign payments may not be made in lei. Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may main- tain accounts with the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade, the National Bank, or with foreign banks having branch offices in Romania. These accounts are of three kinds. A-Accounts are maintained in convertible currency, or in lei obtained for convert- ible currencies, from the selling of precious metals, coins, or ingots, other than silver. B-Accounts are maintained in nonconvertible currencies quoted by the National Bank, in clearing currency, or in lei received from the conversion of such currencies. Transactions in any individual B-Account may be effected in only one such currency. C-Accounts are maintained in lei received from other legal sources. A-Accounts may be debited for payments abroad in any currency, for payments within the country, and for transfers to any other A-, B-, or C-Account. B-Accounts may be debited for all payments abroad in the currencies from which the funds were de- rived and for payments within Romania. C-Ac- counts may be debited only for domestic transac- tions. The transactions permitted for the different accounts do not require any further authorization. Nonresidents may also keep accounts in lei with the Savings and Consignment Bank. The Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade may accept from nonresi- dent customers time deposits in convertible foreign currencies, on which interest is paid at rates prevail- ing in international markets. Romanian citizens, including Romanians work- ing abroad who transfer their savings to Romania, may open foreign currency accounts with the Roma- nian Bank for Foreign Trade or the National Bank. The deposits may be used for payments in foreign currency, at home or abroad, or for exchange into lei at the noncommercial exchange rate. The entire amount of foreign exchange received from abroad for special purposes for the benefit of Romanian citizens (such as the building or purchasing of a house, the purchase of an automobile, the purchase of other goods or services whose prices are ex- pressed in foreign currency, travel abroad, and other purposes) may be used by the recipients. For certain other foreign exchange receipts from abroad, such as inheritances, donations, assistance, or family maintenance, a proportion may be depos- ited in a foreign currency account and the rest must be converted into lei at the noncommercial ex- change rate. Imports and Exports The administrative framework for planning and executing foreign trade in Romania is provided in the Foreign Trade Law (Law No. 12 of Decem- ber 1980). International economic activity is or- ganized and carried out in accordance with the principle of working people's self-management and self-administration of economic, financial, and foreign exchange. The general policy targets for foreign trade are set at the central level. Import and export plans are drawn up by the basic economic units, production enterprises, and industrial centrals on the basis of current and long-term needs. The foreign trade plan specifies only a limited number of goods considered of particular importance for the national economy, especially raw materials. The total planned trade does not separate importing or exporting countries but distinguishes between the clearing area and the convertible currency area, according to the manner of settlement of exchange payments and receipts. Import and export transactions are carried out on the basis of authorizations issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade and International Economic Coopera- tion for each commodity or group of commodities. The authorizations are not restrictive or discrimina- tory and may be issued, at the request of foreign trade units, for all types of goods, regardless of origin. The Ministry may take measures to curb imports, with a view to equilibrating the balance of payments, for the protection of public health, and for reasons of national defense and the security of the State, etc., in accordance with the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). As a rule, annual import authorizations expressed in value terms are issued to individual importing enterprises as a lump sum or for a single kind of product. The authorization stipulates whether import payments are to be made in con- vertible currency or under bilateral payments ar- rangements, and, in the latter case, the country is also specified. Export proceeds must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade. Imports for investment in complex installations (assemblies, subassemblies, machinery, equip- ment, and spare parts) are delivered to the buying units at domestic prices that are equal to the customs value (calculated by multiplying the exter- nal price by the commercial rate), plus customs duties. Imports of consumer goods are delivered to the commercial purchasing units at retail prices, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ROMANIA 405 less the commercial discount. The difference be- tween prices so derived and prices calculated on the basis of customs value plus customs duties and, in some cases, the turnover tax, is reflected in the financial accounts of the importing foreign trade unit. Imports are subject to customs duties, although duties are not applied to 121 tariff positions and subpositions. Customs duties are temporarily not being levied on imports of raw materials, assem- blies, subassemblies, and spare parts for produc- tion, repair, and maintenance, totaling about 500 tariff positions and subpositions. The customs tariff is nondiscriminatory. Decree No. 337/1981, issued on November 26,1981, increased tariffs on personal imports of certain items into Romania above the value limits for the specified goods. The import goods prohibited to individuals include passenger cars with high fuel consumption, minibuses, fire- arms, and air conditioners. Customs duties on per- sonal imports of a number of consumer durables, such as motorcycles and electrical appliances, are levied at rates of between 100 percent and 300 per- cent above the applicable customs tar iff. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles All transactions in invisibles not connected with foreign trade transactions require general or indi- vidual authorization given by either the Ministry of Finance or another appropriate ministry. For most categories of payments in respect of invisibles, for- eign exchange is made available automatically once the transaction has been authorized. For travel out- side the socialist countries, an exchange allocation is provided up to the equivalent of US$70 a trip for each adult. In addition, tourist agencies may orga- nize group or individual trips payable in lei. Re- ceipts from transactions in invisibles must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade, and the for- eign currency required for payments in respect of such transactions is bought from the same bank. With specified exceptions, travelers with perma- nent residence in nonsocialist countries must con- vert at least US$10 a person a day (or the equivalent in other "acceptable" currencies)4 during their stay in Romania. This requirement does not apply to (1) holders of diplomatic service passports and their 4The acceptable currencies, in addition to the U.S. dollar, are Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Greek drachmas, Indian rupees, Israeli new sheqalim, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Luxembourg francs, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds ster- ling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, Turkish liras, and Yugoslav dinars. families; (2) newspaper and radio and television correspondents accredited to Romania and their families; (3) persons studying in Romania and their spouses; (4) permanent foreign personnel of foreign firms or agencies authorized to operate in Romania (including joint ventures) and their families; (5) guests of socialist units and of other juridical persons in Romania, as well as of international or- ganizations having their headquarters in Romania; (6) children under 14; (7) teachers visiting Romania under agreements for cultural, technical, and scien- tific cooperation and their families; (8) persons who can be shown to have made payments for tourist services; (9) foreign personnel in assembly work or providing technical assistance in Romania and their families; (10) persons of Romanian origin having foreign citizenship or who are stateless; (11) Ro- manian citizens possessing a valid Romanian pass- port who are domiciled abroad; (12) persons resi- dent abroad without a valid Romanian passport, but who have not renounced their Romanian cit- izenship; and (13) parents, spouses, and children of persons in categories (10)-(12). Foreign diplomats and tourists, as well as Romanian citizens legally holding foreign currencies, may purchase certain domestically produced or imported consumer goods in specialized shops, against payment in con- vertible currencies. Foreign tourists may purchase domestically produced and certain imported con- sumer goods in specialized shops, against payment in convertible currencies. The import and export of Romanian notes and coin by travelers are pro- hibited, with the exception of those coming from CMEA member countries, Albania, and the Demo- cratic People's Republic of Korea; these latter may each bring in or take out up to lei 500 a trip in accordance with agreements concluded with these countries. Capital All inward and outward transfers of foreign ex- change must be authorized by the Ministry of Fi- nance. Outward transfers of funds belonging to resident physical persons are not normally permit- ted. For certain established categories, such as in- heritances, reciprocal agreements have been con- cluded with a number of countries providing for automatic authorization of transfers of specified amounts to and from Romania. The Foreign Trade Law provides for the establish- ment of joint ventures in Romania and abroad by Romanian economic organizations. Foreigners are also allowed to invest capital in joint ventures in Romania, up to 49 percent of the total capital of the company concerned. The Foreign Trade Law and ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 406 ROMANIA implementing decrees guarantee the repatriation in foreign currency of the capital and the transfer in foreign currency of profits after taxes. By agree- ment, the accounts of joint ventures may be kept in an agreed currency. Bank, in turn, authorizes certain juridical persons to hold gold, to use it, and to engage in gold transac- tions. The ownership by physical persons, for do- mestic and personal use, of jewelry and of artistic and cultural objects of gold is not restricted. Gold The National Bank has sole authority to purchase or sell gold in any manner, at home or abroad.
