Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Uruguay is the Uruguayan New Peso. Uruguay follows a floating exchange rate pol- icy under which the exchange rate of the Uruguayan new peso is determined by market forces, although the Central Bank reserves the right, in principle, to intervene for the purpose of preventing disorderly conditions in the exchange market. Buying and sell- ing interbank rates for the U.S. dollar, the inter- vention currency, on December 30, 1988 were NUr$450.0 and NUr$451.0, respectively, per US$1. Rates for other currencies are based on U.S. dollar rates in exchange markets abroad. A tax of 1.5 percent is levied on sales of foreign exchange in both the spot and forward exchange markets, if a transaction is settled in Uruguayan new pesos; the tax rate is 0.05 percent for sales of foreign exchange through interbank operations. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk in the official or the com- mercial banking sector. Export proceeds are required to be negotiated in the banking system. (The term "negotiate" means that export proceeds may be converted into other currencies or used to pay off obligations or generate other assets.) There are no limits on the amount of foreign exchange that the Central Bank may sell to or buy from the Bank of the Republic, the Mortgage Bank, commercial banks, and banking and ex- change houses. Uruguay formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agree- ment, as from May 2, 1980. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through authorized banks, banking houses, exchange houses, and the Bank of the Republic. Any person or firm may conduct exchange transactions in the market, provided this does not become a customary business. Exchange houses must be authorized by the Central Bank. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agreements may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the multilateral clearing system of the Latin American Integration Associa- tion (LAIA); these countries are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Para- guay, Peru, and Venezuela. There are separate ar- rangements for trade in specified goods with Ar- gentina, Brazil, and Mexico, among other countries. All settlements of balances under the multilateral clearing system are made in U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration before the goods are shipped. The registrations are generally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. Most imports are subject to import surcharges. The surcharge rates are within a range of 10- 45 percent and are payable to the Bank of the Re- public at the time of registration. Full or partial exemption from these surcharges is granted for im- ports from member countries of the LAIA, imports of agricultural inputs, imports by the public sector, imports of machinery, equipment, tools, and spare parts for certain priority industries, and imports under the temporary admission scheme. The Bank of the Republic also collects a consular charge of 4 percent on the f .o.b. value of imports, with certain exemptions. Most imports are also subject to a customs tariff (impuesto aduanero unico, IMADUNI) and a service charge (tasa de movilizacion de bultos, TMB), collected by the Customs Office. Tariff rates vary between zero and 15 percent. The service charge is 1 percent of the c . i .f. import price for most imports. There are exemptions to IMADUNI and TMB. The combined effective tariff rate (including surcharges, tariffs, consular fees, and service charges) is limited to a maximum of 45 percent. Import surcharges, IMADUNI, and TMB are calcu- lated either on an officially assesed price (precio de referenda), on a minimum export price, or on the actual c .i .f. value, whichever is the highest. Payments for Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for invis- ibles or the export of foreign or domestic bank notes. Exports and Export Proceeds Foreign exchange proceeds from exports must be negotiated in the banking system not later than 520 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY 521 36 months after the expiration date of shipping doc- uments. Exporters are eligible for rebates in respect of indirect taxes paid during the production pro- cess; these rebates replaced the system of tax credit certificates with effect from January 1, 1983. From time to time, and for special reasons (e.g., stock position, protection, or sanitary considerations), certain exports are forbidden or subjected to special conditions. Some of the traditional exports, such as meat (mutton, beef, and horse), greasy wool (scoured and semiscoured), dry, salted, and pickled hides, and livestock on the hoof (except that of pedigree or pure crossbred), are subject to an export tax at the rate of 5 percent. Fish exports are eligible for tax credit certificates amounting to between 2 percent and 8 percent of the f .o .b. value of exports, which can be used by the exporter to pay taxes or social security contributions, or can be sold to a third party. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no surrender requirements on the pro- ceeds from invisibles, and there are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic bank notes. Capital Inward and outward private capital transfers by either residents or nonresidents may be made freely, with the exception of certain inward and outward transfers relating to investments regis- tered under the Foreign Investment Law. The amor- tization or liquidation proceeds of foreign capital registered under this law cannot normally be trans- ferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad. Changes During 1988 Imports and Import Payments November 9. The import procedures for fruits and vegetables were simplified. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VANUATU (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Vanuatu is the Vatu. Since Febru- ary 5, 1988, the external value of the vatu has been determined on the basis of an undisclosed transactions-weighted basket of currencies. The Central Bank of Vanuatu buys and sells foreign ex- change daily, and buying and selling rates of the vatu against major currencies (Australian dollars, French francs, deutsche mark, Japanese yen, and New Zealand dollars) are quoted within margins of 0.25 percent around the middle rate. The Central Bank deals with the commercial banks only in U.S. dollars on a spot basis, and buys and sells foreign exchange only in transactions with the commercial banks for account of the Government or for com- mercial banks' operations. On December 30, 1988, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar (for telegraphic transfers) were VT 104.79 and VT 105.31 per US$1, respectively. There are no taxes or sub- sidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward exchange rate cover facilities operating in the official sector. As a rule, the commercial banks also do not provide forward exchange rate cover facilities. Vanuatu formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agree- ment, as from December 1, 1982. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency require- ments. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts of resi- dents and nonresidents. Debits and credits to all accounts may be made freely. Imports and Import Payments All items may be freely imported with the excep- tion of the following: any goods that are controlled under internal legislation in the interest of national health and well-being, such as arms and ammuni- tions, explosives, and dangerous drugs; and certain plants, foodstuffs, and animals, which are also re- stricted and subject to authorization. Importation of chicken pieces, canned soft drinks, and T-shirts bearing a Vanuatu motif are restricted through im- port licensing arrangements. A similar restriction is applied to the importation of five basic products— rice, sugar, flour, canned fish, and tobacco products —under a scheme designed to provide funds for the National Cooperative Federation. Three importers pay a commission fee to the Coop- erative for the right to import these five products. Customs duties are levied mainly on an ad va- lorem basis on the c . i .f. value of imports. Certain goods, including spirits, wine, beer, tobacco prod- ucts, and petroleum products, are subject to specific rates of import duty. Imported goods that compete with locally produced equivalents are generally lia- ble to high duty rates. A customs service tax of 5 percent is applied to most imports based on the duty-inclusive import value. Goods imported for a specified end-use may be exempt from import duties. These include goods imported by or on behalf of the Government that are funded by external aid, goods imported for sale to and exported by tourists, ships stores (including fuels), goods imported for processing and re-expor- tation, and goods imported for investment projects. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments for invisibles. Exports and Export Proceeds With a few exceptions, no restrictions are applied on exports. Exports of trochus, green snails, beches- de-mer, and crustaceans1 are subject to authoriza- tion by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries, and Forestry. Copra and cocoa exports are channeled through the Vanuatu Commodities Marketing Board (VCMB), and exports of coffee are subject to authorization from the VCMB. Artifacts that are five years old or more are subject to authorization from the Cultural Center. Most exports are subject to export duties, mainly on an ad valorem basis (f.o.b.); specific duties are levied on some minor exports, including scrap metal and timber. There are no surrender require- ments for export proceeds. including coconut crabs for conservation purposes. 522 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VANUATU 523 Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered. Capital All inward and outward movements of capital are unrestricted. Gold There are no restrictions on gold transactions. Changes During 1988 Exchange Arrangement February 5. The SDR-peg arrangement was re- placed by a peg to an undisclosed transactions- weighted basket of currencies. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Venezuela is the Venezuelan Bolivar. Venezuela maintains a four-tier exchange rate system under which three of the exchange rates are pegged to the U.S. dollar and the fourth is a fluctuating rate.1 In the first market the Central Bank sells foreign exchange to the public in eligible cases at the rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1. The Central Bank may also sell foreign exchange at Bs 4.2925 = US$1 to banks, which may in turn sell to their customers at a rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1. Eligible payments at this preferential rate include those for (1) interest on private external debt authorized by the Differential Exchange System Office (RECADI) that fell due before December 31, 1983; (2) amorti- zation of authorized and registered private external debt (defined as net liability position) eligible for immediate payment;2 and (3) amortization of 10 per- cent of debts other than those eligible for immediate payment. In the second market the Central Bank sells for- eign exchange to the public at the rate of Bs 7.50 = US$1, and to banks at the rate of Bs 7.4925 = US$1 when the banks act as intermediaries, for the pur- pose of: (1) interest payments on external private sector debt registered at RECADI and falling due between December 31,1983 and December 8,1986; (2) current expenditure and capital expenditure abroad by the public authorities and public sector entities; (3) expenditure derived from the interna- tional commitments of the Republic; (4) external Effective March 13, 1989, the multiple exchange rate system was abolished, and the external value of the bolivar was allowed to float in response to the supply and demand conditions in the unified interbank market. Repayments of certain registered pri- vate sector debt and trade credits outstanding before the adop- tion of the new exchange system are being effected at the ex- change rates of Bs 7.50 and Bs 14.50 per US$1, respectively, until December 31, 1989. 2Debts amounting to US$500,000 or less, export credits with foreign official guarantee due before July 17,1986, and debts in the form of certificates of deposit or foreign currency deposits. Debts of between US$500,000 and US$1 million, although eligi- ble for immediate payment, are to be amortized at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1. Export credits with foreign official guarantee due after July 17,1986 can be amortized at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 on their respective dates of maturity, if the debtor sub- scribes to the optional foreign exchange guarantee scheme, ex- cept for the amounts falling due after July 17,1986 but before the signing of a contract between the debtor and the Central Bank, in which case amortization payments can be made immediately at Bs 7.50 per US$1. Amortization payments of private debts that have been assumed by the Government as guarantor are also effected at the rate of BS 7.50 per US$1. public debt interest and amortization payments charged against the budget for fiscal year 1986; (5) external debt servicing of public enterprises, provided the debtor subscribes to the exchange guarantee scheme; and (6) amortization payments on registered private external debt other than those eligible for the Bs 4.30 per US$1 rate,3 and interest on private registered debt falling due after Decem- ber 8, 1986, provided the debtor subscribes to the optional exchange guarantee scheme introduced in December 1986. In the third market the Central Bank buys foreign exchange at the rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1 from the public and public sector entities for the proceeds from exports of goods and services (excluding tour- ism) and all public and registered private capital imports; it sells foreign exchange in the same mar- ket to the public at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1, and to banks at the rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1 when the banks act as intermediaries, for the purpose of: (1) all authorized imports of goods and services (excluding tourism); (2) public sector current pay- ments abroad and payments related to international commitments of the Government of Venezuela; (3) outward remittances to certain students abroad during 1987, and to all students abroad after De- cember 31, 1987; (4) interest and amortization pay- ments on external debt contracted or serviced by the Central Government; and (5) private debt amortiza- tion payments on registered debts eligible for but not covered by the optional exchange rate guarantee scheme. In the fourth market transactions take place at a freely fluctuating rate; this rate applies to tourism transactions and nonregistered private capital flows. The Central Bank may buy and sell foreign exchange at the fluctuating rate market, which oper- ates through financial intermediaries. The banks and exchange houses in this market may establish different exchange rates according to the instru- ment being transacted, but the spread between buying and selling rates for the same instrument may not exceed Bs 0.05 per US$1 in the case of banks, and Bs 0.15 per US$1 in the case of exchange 3I.e., debts of between US$500,000 and US$1 million, export credits with official guarantees falling due between July 17,1986 and the date of the signing of the contracts between the debtor and the Central Bank, and 90 percent of the debts covered pre- viously under the five-year rescheduling scheme, provided the debtor subscribes to the optional guarantee scheme introduced in December 1986. 524 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA 525 houses. On December 30, 1988, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the commercial bank market were Bs 39.10 and Bs 39.15 per US$1, respectively. Buying and selling rates for other officially quoted currencies4 are based, for each market, on the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in major markets abroad. There are no taxes or sub- sidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. In the case of interbank transfers, domestic banks may charge only the cost of the transfer, including com- mission and other charges by the foreign banks. Under the exchange rate guarantee scheme, debtors can acquire guaranteed access to foreign exchange at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 by paying a premium (see section on Capital, below). As regards import operations using foreign exchange from the official market, cover is available as follows: (1) if the operation is covered by letters of credit, the ex- change rate applicable for paying for the import will be the rate prevailing when the letter of credit is opened, provided no more than 360 days have elapsed since the date on which the letter of credit was opened; (2) if the operation is carried out using facilities other than a letter of credit, the exchange rate applicable for the payment will be the rate pre- vailing on the date of shipment of the goods or, if the goods have not been shipped, on the date the legal documentation is issued attesting to the commit- ment assumed by the importer; (3) if the imports are effected in cash, the exchange rate applicable to the payment will be maintained for a period of 180 days from the date of shipment of the merchandise; and (4) if the import is financed with suppliers' credits, the exchange rate applicable to the transfer will be maintained for 360 consecutive days from the date of shipment of the merchandise. Venezuela formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agree- ment on July 1, 1976. Administration of Control Foreign exchange policies are established by the Ministry of Finance, with the advice of the Differen- tial Exchange System Advisory Committee. The committee is chaired by the Minister of Finance and includes the Minister of Development, the Minister of Agriculture and Livestock, the Minister of the Central Coordination and Planning Office, the Pres- ident of the Central Bank of Venezuela, and the President of the Venezuelan Investment Fund. The 4Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, and Swiss francs. exchange control system is administered by the Central Bank and the Ministry of Finance. Import and export licenses are generally issued by the Min- istry of Development or the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, depending on the commodity. Im- port quotas and prohibitions within the multiple exchange rate system are established by the Minis- try of Finance. The Superintendency of Foreign In- vestments (SIEX) exercises supervision over foreign investment in Venezuela, over contracts for the im- portation of foreign technology and the use of for- eign patents and trademarks, and over borrowing abroad. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, the Domini- can Republic, Ecuador, Jamaica, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts main- tained with each other by the Central Bank of Vene- zuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. Imports and Import Payments Imports from South Africa are prohibited. In ad- dition, importation of certain goods is either pro- hibited or reserved for the Government; these in- clude iron and steel products, luxury food, apparel, and specified consumer durables. Certain other commodities also require import licenses. For pro- tective purposes, quantitative restrictions are main- tained on some of these items, irrespective of origin, except in the case of Andean Pact and Latin America Integration Association (LAIA) member countries. Licenses are valid for all countries except South Africa. Import licenses for some goods are issued on evidence that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quantity to be imported. Payments for imports that are not prohibited, re- served for the public sector, or subject to special regimes may be made at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1 when authorized by RECADI, or at the free market rate. To have access to foreign exchange from the Central Bank for payment of imports, an importer must obtain an import license (conformidad de impor- tation) from the Directorate of Imports and the Min- istry of Finance before the date of shipment of the goods; the license has a validity of 180 days, and may be renewed up to a period determined by the Directorate in each specific case. Import licenses are granted on the basis of semiannual import pro- grams, which are approved for each individual firm at the beginning of each year. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 526 VENEZUELA In the case of imports channeled through the official market and not effected through a letter of credit, importers must submit the import license to the Central Bank within 90 banking days from the date of customs clearance. The importer may obtain from the Central Bank the foreign exchange to settle his obligations as they become due, up to the total amount authorized in the import license, within 25 banking days after 120 days have elapsed since the date of shipment of the goods. In the case of imports effected through letters of credit, the importer may obtain from the Central Bank foreign exchange for the equivalent of up to 20 percent of the amount authorized in the import license. In the case of imports of raw materials for the manufacture of goods intended for exports by exporting firms registered with the Foreign Trade Institute, the importer may obtain from the Central Bank foreign exchange for the equivalent of up to 50 percent of the amount authorized in the import license issued by the Foreign Trade Institute. In both cases, the Central Bank issues a Certificate of Availability of Foreign Exchange for the total amount authorized minus the amount released ear- lier, which is valid for 360 days from the date of opening of the letter of credit. The importer must submit this certificate to the Central Bank (within 90 banking days from the date of customs clearance) to obtain from the Central Bank (within 25 banking days after 120 days have elapsed since the date of shipment of the goods) the remaining foreign ex- change to settle the obligations under the letter of credit as they fall due. In the case of imports effected directly by public sector entities, foreign exchange equivalent to up to 100 percent of the authorized amount in the import license issued by the Ministry of Finance will be provided by the Central Bank within 60 days after submission by the public sector agency of the im- port license to the Central Bank. In accordance with the timetable issued by the Andean Pact Commission contained in the Protocol of Lima, Venezuela adopted the minimum external tariff in 1978 (Decree No. 2772 of August 3,1978). It agreed, in principle, to harmonize external tariffs and eliminate all import duties on trade within the Andean subregion by December 31, 1983 in the prescribed annual stages. Payments for Invisibles Interest payments on registered private external debt falling due before December 31, 1983 are al- lowed to be made through the preferential rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1. Interest payments on public and registered private external debt falling due after De- cember 31, 1983, including interest on private or public entities' debts falling due after December 6, 1986 if the debtor chooses to opt for the exchange rate guarantee scheme, may be made at the rate of Bs 7.50 = US$1. The following invisible payments are effected at the rate of Bs 14.50 per US$1: (1) freight, insurance, and import-financing costs associated with imports made at this rate; (2) interest on the external debt of the Central Gov- ernment or serviced by the Central Government; (3) other public sector current payments abroad; (4) outward remittances to students; and (5) interest payments on registered private debts not covered by the exchange rate guarantee scheme. Other payments for invisibles can be made through the free market without limit. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to South Africa are prohibited. Ex- ports of certain furs and hides, scrap metal, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the export of commodities subject to price controls or deemed to be in short supply do- mestically; for most commodities, such licenses are issued by the Ministry of Development, but those for coffee, cacao, rice, and sugar are granted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. The export of precious stones and gold requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. All export earn- ings by companies dealing in gold must be surren- dered to the Central Bank at the exchange rate it uses for its operations in the free market. In the case of private exporters, the authorization to export is contingent on agreement to sell export proceeds to authorized banks within 30 days of shipment in the case of cash exports, and within 10 days of the due payment date in the case of exports on credit. Re- ceipts from exports other than oil and iron can be surrendered at the rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1, or at the free market exchange rate under two conditions: the exporter must give up access to the fiscal sub- sidy for at least two years; only the domestic value added of exports is eligible for the free market rate, with the import content to be surrendered at the official rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1. Proceeds from exports of oil and iron must be received at the official rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1. Exporters of coffee and cacao may receive an ex- port subsidy calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products on Venezuelan imports from falling below specified minimum amounts, regardless of external prices. In principle, the bene- fit of these arrangements may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. The ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA 527 promotion of nontraditional exports takes four basic forms: (1) the Export Financing Fund, established in September 1973, provides direct credit facilities at interest rates below those charged by other lenders, and it also lends in conjunction with commercial banks; (2) the Export Incentive Law (Septem- ber 1973) assists nontraditional exports through fis- cal subsidies in the form of tax credit certificates; (3) exporters' access to foreign exchange for imports is facilitated; and (4) exporters have the option of surrendering the domestic value added of exports at the free market rate. Under the Export Incentive Law, negotiable tax credit certificates with a two-year maturity are granted to exporters of nontraditional products (i.e., exports other than petroleum, iron ore, coffee, and cacao) that have a domestic value-added con- tent of greater than 30 percent and that are effected at the exchange rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1. These certificates can be held to maturity and used to meet government tax liabilities, or can be traded in the local market at a discount. For the purpose of cal- culating the amount of the export subsidy, the do- mestic currency equivalent of the export value is calculated at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1. For firms exporting more than 15 percent of their production or more than US$250,000 a year, separate semian- nual quotas for imports of raw materials, spare parts, and semifinished products are established at the beginning of each year; the Directorate of Im- ports issues individual import permits on the basis of these firms' applications and within their special import programs. Foreign investment projects or joint ventures with at least 80 percent production for exports may be authorized to effect all foreign ex- change transactions through the free exchange mar- ket, except to the extent needed to cover bolivar operating costs. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are to be sur- rendered at the rate of Bs 14.50 per US$1, except for receipts from tourism, which are freely disposable. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that importation for commercial purposes of foreign coin other than gold coin is prohibited. Capital The national and local governments, autonomous agencies, and state enterprises (other than petro- leum and iron ore companies) are required to sur- render to the Central Bank at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1 all exchange proceeds from foreign borrow- ing; principal repayments on registered external debt of public sector entities are effected at the rate of Bs 7.50 = US$1, if covered by the exchange guar- antee scheme, and principal repayments on the ex- ternal debt contracted or serviced by the Central Government and on debts of public entities not covered by that scheme are effected at the rate of Bsl4.50 = US$1. All foreign exchange brought into Venezuela by the Venezuelan Investment Fund is subject to conversion at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1. Principal repayments of registered external private debt can be effected at the rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1, if the debt amounts to US$500,000 or less and fell due before July 17,1986, and if it is in the form of export credits with foreign official guarantee or in the form of certificates of deposit or foreign currency de- posits. Registered debt amounting to between US$500,000 and US$1 million and export credits with foreign official guarantee due after July 17, 1986, but before the signing of a contract between the debtor and the Central Bank, can be amortized immediately at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1. For the remainder of private registered debts, amortization may take place on the respective dates of maturity at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 under an optional ex- change rate guarantee scheme. Debt eligible for registration was defined as the net liabilities position in foreign exchange as of Feb- ruary 18, 1983 of (1) banking, financial, and insur- ance companies; and (2) nonfinancial enterprises of mixed or Venezuelan ownership in the areas of manufacturing (if the debt was contracted for the acquisition of capital goods for use within the coun- try), transportation and public services (if the debt was for the acquisition of equipment), and con- struction (if the debt was incurred for public sector works or works guaranteed by the public sector for social housing projects). Under the exchange rate guarantee scheme, debtors can acquire guaranteed access to foreign exchange at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 for servicing their registered debts, over a period of eight years, by paying in advance a pre- mium in bolivares. For private debts, the premium is Bs 3 per US$1 for amortization payments, and an additional variable premium of up to Bs 1.50 for each US$1 of registered debt for interest payments.5 A similar exchange rate guarantee scheme exists for external debts of state enterprises and auto- nomous institutions that were contracted before 5The premium varies according to the foreign interest rate under which interest payments are to be covered by the exchange rate guarantee (about Bs 0.17 a percentage point), up to a max- imum rate of 9 percent. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 528 VENEZUELA February 18,1983.6 Debtors have the option of sub- scribing to the exchange rate guarantee for part or all of the amortization payments or for part or all of the interest payments. Any debt-service payments of registered debt eligible for this scheme, but not subscribed to it by the debtor, can be channeled through the controlled exchange market at the rate in effect at the time of payment. In both cases, regardless of whether the exchange guarantee is subscribed, amortization payments are to be effected according to a prescribed (backloaded) schedule, and the interest rate is to be limited to LIBOR plus 1V4 percentage points. Debtors may defer the payment of the premium over the eight- year period, in line with the schedule of debt ser- vice, by paying interest at a rate linked to domestic lending rates. All other inward and outward capital transfers by residents must be registered with SIEX in order to be eligible for the Bs 14.50 per US$1 exchange rate, although they are permitted without restriction in the freely fluctuating exchange market. However, brokerage activity in Venezuela in shares or units of foreign investment trusts or mutual funds is pro- hibited. Foreign capital imported for investment purposes and all foreign credits must be registered with SIEX. Foreign direct investment is governed by Andean Pact regulations; a new foreign investment code, however, has resulted in a substantial liberal- ization of the system. Natural gas and iron mining operations are reserved for the State, and foreign investment in the petroleum sector is prohibited; this restriction may be lifted in exceptional cases. The Central Bank regulates bank credit to nonresi- dents and companies whose capital is more than 50 percent owned by physical persons or companies that are resident or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law authorizes the Government to regu- late bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 percent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. This law also regu- lates the activities of foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Interest earnings on loans extended by foreign financial institutions are exempt from the income tax. Decree No. 1521 and Exchange Agreement No. 4, in combination with the new Foreign Investment Code, regulate the conversion of public sector exter- nal debt into equity or financial assets in Venezuela. Debt-equity conversion is allowed if the intended 6In accordance with the longer repayment period established for such debts, the premium has been set somewhat higher than for private debts (Bs 3.50 for each U.S. dollar of principal, and Bs 0.25 for each percentage point of interest covered). investment is directed either at import substitution, export industries, preventing closure of Venezuelan enterprises, or 1 of 11 priority sectors. For a period of three years, after-tax dividend and profit remit- tances are limited to an annual rate of 10 percent of the converted debt; remittances in subsequent years are subject to the rules of the Foreign Investment Code. No capital repatriation is allowed for a period of five years, and during the following eight years, repatriation is limited to a maximum annual rate of 12.5 percent. The Central Bank acquires the foreign debt at par or at a discount to be determined in each individual case at an exchange rate of Bs 14.4925 per US$1. Debt-equity swaps in exporting industries (firms exporting at least 80 percent of their produc- tion) can be effected at the free market exchange rate, up to a limit of 40 percent of the total invest- ment if the investment does not exceed US$10 mil- lion, or up to a limit of 60 percent if the investment exceeds US$100 million. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment purposes. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coin, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated among authorized importers and exchange houses and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coin among them- selves and with other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as are imports of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Imports and exports of nonmonetary gold (other than jewelry for personal use) and of gold coins eligible as legal tender in Venezuela or abroad are subject to prior authorization by the Cen- tral Bank. In addition, imports require licenses from the Central Bank and in certain cases also from the Minister of Development; exports require authori- zation by the Central Bank. As an incentive mea- sure, export earnings by companies dealing in gold are converted by the Central Bank at the free market rate. The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the Cen- tral Bank as an exporter of gold. Imports of gold are subject to duty at varying rates. Not for Redistribution VIET NAM (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Viet Nam is the Dong. The ex- change rate is quoted in terms of the U.S. dollar to which it is pegged, and adjustments are made at irregular intervals in light of developments in do- mestic and international prices. On February 25, 1988, the exchange rate of the dong for inward remittances was adjusted from D 504 to D 900 per US$1. On September 15, 1988, the exchange rate for the dong for external trade transactions was adjusted from D 225 to D 900 per US$1, thus unifying that exchange rate with the exchange rate for inward remittances. On Novem- ber 10,1988, the exchange rate for the dong for most invisible transactions was adjusted from D 368 to D 2,600 per US$1. The exchange rate for most invis- ible transactions and external trade transactions out- side the foreign exchange plan was further adjusted to D 2,800 per US$1 on December 10 and to D 3,000 per US$1 on December 26, 1988. For external trade transactions outside the plan and for those of local enterprises, the exchange rate for the dong was adjusted from D 900 to D 2,600 per US$1. For exter- nal trade transactions within the plan, the exchange rate of D 900 per US$1 still applies. On Decem- ber 30, 1988, the official exchange rate used for noncommercial transactions was D 3,000 per US$1, and the clearing ruble rate was D 1,080 per one clearing ruble. There are no arrangements for for- ward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the State Bank of Viet Nam. Foreign trade is administered by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, which authorizes the foreign trade transactions carried out by specialized import-export corporations and some cooperatives or state enterprises. Import and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Foreign Eco- nomic Relations; approval is given for imports in excess of the plan on the merit of each application. Most official foreign exchange transactions are effected by the Bank for Foreign Trade. Most of the foreign exchange transactions related to foreign technical assistance are monitored by the Aid Re- ception Commission, which is an agency directly attached to the Cabinet of the Prime Minister. Ar- rears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency Trade transactions with member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA) are settled under the transferable ruble system ad- ministered by the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC). Transactions with Albania, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and the Demo- cratic People's Republic of Korea are settled through individual clearing accounts using clearing (or bilat- eral) rubles. As a member of the CMEA, Viet Nam is entitled to use credits in transferable rubles from the IBEC to facilitate the clearing of transactions with the CMEA member countries. Viet Nam is also entitled to use credits from the IBEC to finance its external trade deficit with the CMEA countries, pending the conclusion of medium- or long-term financing arrangements with the trade parties. Viet Nam maintains a special current account in convert- ible foreign exchange with the IBEC for a petroleum joint venture between Viet Nam and the U.S.S.R. Nontrade transactions with countries with which Viet Nam has bilateral payments agreements1 take place at exchange rates specified in those agreements. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are permitted to maintain nonresi- dent accounts either in foreign currencies or in con- vertible dong. Nonresidents can freely reconvert into foreign currency and transfer abroad unused balances in Vietnamese currency that have been acquired against foreign currency. Imports and Exports An import plan and an export plan are drawn up annually on the basis of the overall annual plan and quotas agreed upon under bilateral trade arrange- ments. Import and export activities are regulated by Decision No. 177, which was issued by the Council of Ministers on June 15,1985 and modified by Deci- sion No. 161 of the Council of Ministers on Octo- ber 1988. Trade transactions are carried out by 28 1 At the end of 1988, Viet Nam maintained bilateral payments agreements with three member countries of the Fund —the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Mali, and the Syrian Arab Re- public (only the agreement with the Lao People's Democratic Republic was operative), and with two countries that are not members of the Fund —Albania and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. 530 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET NAM 531 centrally managed import-export corporations and 22 local trading companies, which produce export- able goods themselves or purchase them from pro- ducers. Some other enterprises can export directly. All payments for external trade transactions are made through the Bank for Foreign Trade; export receipts are also normally channeled through the Bank for Foreign Trade. Local export companies are permitted to export all available commodities, including the 25 items previously under the monopoly of the central export-import companies. Local corporations may import only commodities appearing on a list ap- proved by the Ministry of Foreign Economic Rela- tions, which is amended periodically. The procure- ment prices of exportable commodities and the domestic prices of imported goods are determined by local companies within ranges that are set by the State Pricing Commission for each group of com- modities. In order to make better use of available marketing expertise and facilities, local trading com- panies in the provinces are permitted to enter into joint venture arrangements with trading companies located in various municipalities. Export companies benefit from subsidies when- ever their procurement costs are not fully covered by the international prices of their exports converted to domestic currency at the exchange rate that is applied to trade transactions. For centrally man- aged companies, these subsidies are made available by the Export Support Fund, which is maintained by the Ministry of Finance. For locally managed companies these subsidies are paid out of profits made on imports, with the balance paid by the local government. Export permits are granted only when export subsidies do not exceed pre-established norms. An export bonus system has been in operation since 1980 to provide additional incentives for ex- port production. Since June 15, 1985, the bonus for collective production units (cooperatives, coopera- tion teams, and production collectives) amounts to 4-5 percent of the value in domestic currency of their production of export goods if their plan quota is fulfilled. Central and local companies fulfilling their export quota are granted foreign exchange equivalent to 10 percent of their export earnings to import required inputs. Import corporations receive export subsidies from the budget to cover their pro- duction and procurement costs, and the export sub- sidy fund that is operated for this purpose is fi- nanced by profits from import sales. Following the fulfillment of the export plan against the delivery of input by the Government, export-producing enterprises are entitled either to retain 10-30 percent of export earnings in deposits in foreign currencies or to use foreign exchange at their discretion; the remainder must be surrendered to the Government. In the case of exports not cov- ered by the plan, the enterprises are entitled either to retain 70-90 percent of export earnings in de- posits in foreign currencies or to use foreign ex- change at their discretion; the remainder must be surrendered to the Government. Local trading companies are also required to sur- render 10-30 percent of their export earnings (in convertible currencies) that exceed the quota deliv- ered to the State. However, many exemptions cur- rently apply. For localities that borrow in foreign currency, the surrender requirement is applied to their export earnings, net of their debt-servicing payments, for a period of three to five years; com- panies operating in the highland area are exempted from surrendering foreign exchange for a period of five years after they start producing exportable goods. Centrally managed companies operating in the tourist sectors are exempted from the surrender requirement, and central companies exporting coal, rubber, and marine products are allowed to retain 80-100 percent of their export earnings to purchase necessary inputs from the convertible area. De- posits arising from foreign currency receipts are held in special domestic currency accounts that can be used for the purchase of foreign currency for imports. The right to use these convertible dong deposits can be relinquished to other enterprises in exchange for the supply of inputs. State enterprises have two export plans. Primary export plans are formulated by the Government against deliveries of key inputs by the Government; secondary plans are set by the producing units without a sufficient supply of inputs (e.g., fuel) by the Government, thus leaving the task of procuring the needed inputs to the enterprises. New taxes on international trade became effective in early 1988. Import duties ranging from 5 percent to 55 percent, with the majority of rates not exceed- ing 20 percent, were introduced. The lowest rates are levied on imports of raw materials and capital equipment, and the highest rates are levied on im- ports of consumer goods classified as luxuries (pre- viously, import duties were levied only on noncom- mercial imports, and this duty was retained). The export taxes for most products range up to 10 per- cent. The taxes on international trade are calculated on the basis of the exchange rate applied to trade transactions. For imports from the nonconvertible currency area, annual foreign exchange is allocated to im- porters on the basis of actual production capacity; in ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 532 VIET NAM principle, such foreign exchange cannot be carried over from one year to the next. For imports from the convertible area, although a similar foreign ex- change allocation system exists in principle, it is not in use, as decisions to allocate foreign exchange are taken by the Prime Minister's Cabinet on a case-by- case basis, on recommendations from the State Planning Commission, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, and spec- ified Vice-Premiers. For transactions under the local production plans, local authorities are authorized to decide on foreign exchange allocation, provided that the resources are derived from their retained export earnings. Payments for Invisibles All transactions in invisibles require individual authorization by the Ministry of Finance. Foreign exchange is made available upon authorization of the transaction. All travel abroad needs individual authorization from the Prime Minister's Cabinet and is limited to official businesses for which all reasonable foreign exchange expenses are covered.2 Receipts from transactions in invisibles must be sur- rendered to the Ministry of Finance. The export and import of Vietnamese currency and of securities denominated in Vietnamese cur- rency need the special permission of the State Bank. As of October 1988, Vietnamese citizens having for- eign currency are allowed to sell it to banks at com- mercial exchange rates, to make purchases at shops selling goods for foreign exchange, and to deposit it into bank accounts bearing interest on foreign cur- rency at interest rates set by the bank. Foreign cur- rency deposited with a bank may be withdrawn for payment or transfer to other units or individuals. Legal holders of foreign exchange are authorized to buy foreign and local consumer goods in special government shops, and tourists are required to make certain payments in convertible foreign currency. Capital A new law on foreign investment was approved by the National Assembly on December 29, 1987, providing for three forms of foreign investment: (1) contracted business cooperation, such as product-sharing arrangements; (2) joint ventures between a foreign investor and a Vietnamese state 2As of February 1988, private travel has been permitted for specified reasons, including study, health, and visiting relatives abroad. In the latter case, the traveler must have a round-trip ticket and adequate funds provided by transfers from the rela- tives abroad. economic organization; and (3) categories wholly owned by foreign investors. The permitted share of foreign capital is to be no less than 30 percent, and there is no upper limit. Other provisions under the Investment Code include: (1) the duration of the enterprise with foreign capital, not to exceed 20 years, but if necessary, to be extended for a longer period; (2) a tax of 5-10 percent, to be levied on remittance of profits abroad; (3) income taxes, to be paid at the reduced rates of 15-25 percent, starting two years after the first profit-making year; and (4) possible exemptions from or reductions of import and export duties in exceptional cases. The Code also provides that foreign investors need to deal only with one organization within the Government specifically created for that purpose. Beginning in October 1988, Vietnamese organiza- tions and citizens who need foreign currency for production and business purposes are permitted, upon verification by competent agencies, to borrow foreign currency or get a bank guarantee for loans in foreign currency. If allowed to borrow directly from foreign countries under commercial credit, the bor- rower must report periodically to the State Bank the expenditures in foreign currency from funds depos- ited abroad, including loan repayments. Gold The State Bank alone has the authority to pur- chase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Individuals are permitted to own jewelry and artistic and cultural objects of gold for domestic and personal use. Changes During 1988 Exchange Arrangement February 25. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Western Samoa is the Western Samoa Tala. The exchange rate of the tala is deter- mined on the basis of a weighted basket of curren- cies. On December 30,1988, the buying and selling rates of the tala in terms of the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, were WS$1 = US$0.4701 and WS$1 = US$0.4611, respectively. Exchange rates for other currencies are established on the basis of their daily rates against the U.S. dollar. There is an exchange levy of 1 percent on gross sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk in the official or the commercial banking sector. Administration of Control Overall responsibility for the administration of exchange control rests with the Central Bank of Samoa, which delegates part of its powers to autho- rized banks. In principle, all payments to nonresi- dents of Western Samoa require the approval of the Central Bank of Samoa; the Bank of Western Samoa and the Pacific Commercial Bank —the only autho- rized banks—are empowered to approve certain payments up to any amount, and certain other pay- ments up to specified amounts. Prescription of Currency There are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which payments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of residents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Nonresidents may, with the approval of the Central Bank, open external or foreign currency accounts with one of the two commercial banks. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited for reasons of security or health. Other commodities may be imported from any source without restric- tion, with the exception of items subject to special approval by the Central Bank on a case-by-case basis, namely timber, motor vehicles, and capital equipment with a c.i.f. value in excess of WS$10,000. In addition, all imports with a c.i.f. value in excess of WS$10,000 are in each case re- quired to be settled under letters of credit. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles may be approved by the authorized banks up to specified limits. Pay- ments in excess of these limits, as well as payments for all other invisibles, require the prior approval of the Central Bank. The Central Bank approval pro- cess that governs the remittance of invisible pay- ments is concerned only with the bona fide nature of the transaction. Residents and expatriates traveling overseas for private purposes are entitled to a for- eign currency allowance equivalent to WS$200 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$3,000 a person a trip; children under 15 years of age are entitled to 50 percent of the adult allowances. In the case of travel for business purposes, the daily allowance is WS$300 with a limit of WS$4,500 a trip. The Central Bank of Samoa grants supplementary allocations against evidence of legitimate need (such as medical expenses). As part of their foreign currency al- lowance, resident travelers may take out foreign bank notes equivalent to WS$1,000 a person a trip. Travelers may not take out any domestic currency. A 15 percent withholding tax is levied on remittances of dividends at the source and interest payments on overseas loans. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require export licenses issued by the Customs Department. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agriculture and the Produce Mar- keting Division on grounds of low quality, or by order of the head of state to alleviate domestic short- ages. Exports of cocoa are controlled by the Cocoa Board. An export levy of 7 percent is imposed on the f.o.b. value of cocoa.1 Export proceeds from goods shipped to countries other than American Samoa must be surrendered to the authorized banks within three months of the date of shipment; export proceeds from goods shipped to American Samoa must be surrendered to the authorized bank within four weeks of the date of shipment. Certificates validated by an authorized bank are required for exports in excess of WS$250. 1PThe export levy on cocoa is activated at prices in excess of WS$800 a ton. 534 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA 535 The following rates of export levies are applied: copra, 5 percent, activated at prices in excess of WS$100 a ton; copra meal, 3 percent; fruits and vegetables, 3 percent; veneer logs and sawn logs, 20 percent; rough timber, 5 percent to 15 percent; and coconut oil, WS$25 a metric ton. Proceeds from Invisibles All foreign currencies earned by residents in per- forming services for nonresidents must be surren- dered to the authorized banks. Resident travelers must on return sell to the banks all unused foreign currency brought in. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign bank notes but may not bring in any domestic bank notes. Capital All outward capital transfers by residents require the specific approval of the Central Bank of Samoa. Inward capital remittances do not normally require approval, but borrowing abroad by all residents (in- cluding banks) requires prior approval of the Cen- tral Bank. Authorized banks may approve transfers of gifts to relatives and dependents, either for spe- cial family occasions or by way of maintenance, up to WS$250 a year a person. Requests for larger amounts may be approved by the Central Bank on a case-by-case basis. Foreign investments in specified activities in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises Incentive Act provides for the granting of certain relief of income tax and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Both the repatriation of capital and profit remit- tances on foreign capital are subject to approval by the Central Bank of Samoa; such approval is nor- mally granted. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form. There are no restrictions on im- ports or exports of gold. Changes During 1988 Imports and Import Payments December 1. The following imports were liber- alized and no longer required prior central bank approval: beer, cigarettes, veneer, matches, ciga- rette lighters, sandals/thongs, soft drinks, and ice cream products. Foreign exchange allowances for pri- vate and business travel were increased from WS$100 a day (WS$2,000 a trip) and WS$200 a day (WS$4,000 a trip) to WS$200 a day (WS$3,000 a trip) and WS$300 a day (WS$4,500 a trip), respectively. Only WS$1,000 of these allowances may be taken out of the country in foreign currency notes. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1988) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, at YRls 9.76 = US$1. On De- cember 30,1988, the official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were YRls 9.75 and YRls 9.77, respectively, per US$1. Buying and selling rates for 12 other currencies1 are fixed daily by the Central Bank of Yemen, on the basis of rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. The Central Bank is the sole buyer and seller of foreign exchange in the domestic banking system. It purchases foreign exchange mainly from money changers (mainly in Jeddah) who acquire foreign exchange from Y. A.R. workers in Saudi Arabia, and credits the accounts of the money changers with commercial banks in the Yemen Arab Republic. Commercial banks are allowed to purchase foreign exchange domestically (from customers and tour- ists) but must sell any foreign exchange acquired to the Central Bank. The Central Bank provides for- eign exchange to all holders of import licenses at the official exchange rate. An exchange rate of YRls 10 = US$1 is used for the settlement of letters of credit. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk operating in the official or the commercial banking sector. There is an informal market for foreign exchange involving small money changers who, although le- gally not permitted to operate in foreign exchange transactions, transact in small amounts and within reasonable margins. Administration of Control A foreign exchange budget is established by the Central Bank in parallel with a commodity budget prepared by the Ministry of Economy, Commerce, and Supply in consultation with the Central Bank. All imports require a license issued by the Ministry of Economy, Commerce, and Supply. However, since 1988, all enterprises have been permitted to import spare parts up to a maximum value of US$1,000 for each shipment without licenses to meet emergency requirements. The value of im- ports under this facility is not allowed to exceed US$5,000 a month for each enterprise. Transactions in invisibles are supervised by the Central Bank. All commercial banks operate in the foreign exchange market only as agents of the Central Bank. They are not allowed to buy or sell foreign exchange for their own account or for the accounts of their customers. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency require- ments. Settlements may be made in any currency. Imports and Import Payments An annual foreign exchange budget is prepared by the Central Bank, and is approved by the Eco- nomic Committee of the Council of Ministers and the Prime Minister. In conjunction with the foreign exchange budget, an import program is prepared annually by the Ministry of Economy, Commerce, and Supply. The priority categories are foodstuffs, petroleum products, medicines, and inputs for production. Imports from Israel and imports of certain types of used machinery for resale are prohibited. All other imports require licenses and must be pro- cessed through local commercial banks. In addition, the importation of certain products requires the per- mission of certain government agencies, and im- ports of petroleum products are reserved for the Yemen Petroleum Company (YPC), a public corpo- ration. With the exception of medical imports, in- surance for all imports must be purchased locally. All importers holding an import license can ob- tain the necessary foreign exchange from the Cen- tral Bank. Y.A.R. nationals returning from abroad who use their savings in foreign exchange to estab- lish small enterprises or craft shops are allowed to import machinery and spare parts needed for their business activities up to a limit of US$40,000 only with the authorization of the Ministry of Economy. Margin deposits (which earn no interest) are pre- scribed against letters of credit opened for imports, as follows: 25 percent for foodstuffs, medical sup- plies, fuel, raw materials, spare parts, and building materials; and 50 percent for all other products.2 In 1 Deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Jordan dinars, Kuwaiti dinars, Lebanese pounds, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Saudi Arabian riyals, Swedish kronor, and Swiss francs. 2The deposit requirement was abolished, effective April 1, 1989. The commercial banks may require, on their own discre- tion, deposits against letters of credit. 536 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC 537 addition to the applicable customs duty, imports are subject to a defense tax of 5 percent, a statistical tax of 2 percent, and a tax of 1 percent for reconstruction related to earthquake damage. Since 1985, imports transported over land routes without a license have been subject to a 100 percent surcharge and an advance payment of profits tax equal to 3 percent of their value. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely. The Central Bank (through its agents, the commercial banks) sells foreign exchange to travelers and those seeking medical treatment abroad, with the amount dependent on their destination. In addition, there are limits on the amount of foreign exchange com- mercial banks may sell to travelers. There is an over- all monthly limit of US$15,000 for each commercial bank on foreign exchange sales to travelers, a limit of US$1,500 on foreign exchange sales to each indi- vidual traveler, and a limit of US$4,000 on foreign exchange sales to a person going abroad for medical treatment. Larger amounts are granted with per- mission from the Central Bank, which is granted routinely. The Central Bank also routinely grants permission for travelers to take out larger amounts of their own foreign exchange. There are no restric- tions on outward remittances in foreign exchange by expatriate employees. Travelers can freely take out bank notes of up to YRls 50,000 or the equivalent in other currencies without prior permission of the Central Bank. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. For statistical purposes only, all exports must be registered on forms that are issued freely by banks; export li- censes are not required. Non-petroleum exporters may use 100 percent of their foreign exchange re- ceipts to finance imports either of their own inputs, or any other permitted goods, as long as they have an import license. Exporters do not have to sur- render their foreign exchange proceeds, which may be retained in foreign currency accounts with do- mestic banks. Exporters of qat are subject to an export duty of 12 percent. Capital Although inward and outward capital transfers are not restricted, they are subject to the provisions of the Investment Law administered by the Ministry of Industry. For approved and registered projects, this law guarantees freedom of investment, equal treatment of foreigners and nationals, the transfer abroad of net profits after taxes attributable to foreign capital, and the repatriation of registered capital on liquida- tion in the currency of investment. In practice, in- vestors are free to transfer abroad any portion of their share of net profits after taxes and other provi- sions and to repatriate their capital. Nationalization and confiscation are prohibited, except in cases of urgent public necessity, and then only with com- pensation and permission to transfer foreign capital abroad. Direct investments are authorized by the Ministry of Industry upon determination that the project is economically viable and socially accept- able; a reasonable timetable for completion and other conditions must be specified. Certain tax and import duty exemptions and concessions are granted for a period of five years to approved proj- ects that meet specific economic criteria. Private capital transactions unrelated to direct investments may also be made without restriction. The registra- tion of direct foreign investments and the authen- tication of intended profit and capital repatriation are undertaken by the Ministry of Industry in coop- eration with the Central Bank. External public debt transactions are conducted through the Central Bank, which also maintains accounts of outstand- ing amounts and service payments due. Gold Residents are free to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in the Yemen Arab Republic and to import or export gold in any form without an im- port, export, or exchange license.
